Module nl.naturalis.common

Package nl.naturalis.common.function

package nl.naturalis.common.function
Classes and interfaces related to functional programming. Two categories of interfaces can be distinguished in this package:
  1. The Relation interface and its sister interfaces
  2. Variants of existing JDK interfaces that distinguish themselves from their JDK counterparts by allowing a checked exception to be thrown from the functional method (for example Function vs. ThrowingFunction). These variants may not be amenable to stream programming, let alone in concurrent fashion, but they are nevertheless very useful and are used throughout in the other packages of naturalis-common.

The Relation interface

The Relation interface and its sister interfaces in this package assess the presence of a relationship between two values. The values may or may not have the same type. The value being assessed is called the subject of the relationship, and the value that it forms the relationship with is called the object of the relationship. If the subject does indeed have the sought-after relation to the object, the relation is said to exist. For example, if x is a Collection and y is an element of it, then the contains relation (Collection::contains) exists between x and y. The CommonChecks class from Naturalis Check defines (or aliases) many small Relation implementations (like Collection::contains) that can be used as checks on arguments

(NB following the JDK's nomenclature the Relation interface might also have been termed a BiPredicate, because that is basically what it is. No such interface exists, by the way, in the JDK.)

  • Related Packages
    Package
    Description
    nl.naturalis.common
    Contains various static method utility classes for working with strings, arrays, collections, etc.
  • Interfaces
    Class
    Description
    IntObjRelation<T>
    Defines a relationship between an integer and an object.
    IntRelation
    Defines a relationship between two integers.
    ObjIntRelation<T>
    Defines some kind of relationship between an object and an integer.
    Relation<T,U>
    Defines a relationship between two objects.
    ThrowingBiFunction<T,U,R,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's BiFunction interface where the apply method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingConsumer<T,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's Consumer interface where the accept method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingFunction<T,R,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's Function interface where the apply method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingIntConsumer<X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's IntConsumer interface where the accept method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingIntFunction<R,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's IntFunction interface where the apply method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingIntSupplier<X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's IntSupplier interface where the get method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingSupplier<T,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's Supplier interface where the get method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
    ThrowingToIntFunction<T,X extends Throwable>
    An alternative to Java's ToIntFunction interface where the apply method is allowed to throw a checked exception.
